To Professor Hans Dieter Lüke (1935–2005), in memoriam This paper discusses the work of Herbert Raabe (1909–2004) and its significance in terms of sampling. Raabe's thesis, published in 1939, represents a milestone in the development of sampling, as pointed out in the historical works of Lüke. Raabe built and analysed the first time-division multiplex system for telephony, a task that required of him a thorough understanding of sampling, including sampling with pulses of finite duration and sampling of low-pass and band-pass signals. We analyse his approach, its significance from the viewpoint of sampling, the generality of its conclusions, and also the milieu that lead to his remarkable achievements: the exceptional research climate existing in Berlin at the time he worked. We also examine the connection between “Raabe's condition”, the work of Harry Nyquist (1924, 1928) on telegraphy and the so-called “Nyquist rate”. An English translation of the sections of Raabe's dissertation more closely related to sampling is included as an appendix. Keywords Sampling Multiplexing Raabe's condition Nyquist rate Historical review 1 Introduction Herbert Raabe's contribution to the sampling theorem only became known after the important historical studies by Lüke [1–4]. Raabe deduced a form of the sampling theorem in his doctoral thesis Untersuchungen an der Wechselzeitigen Multiplexübertragung and published it in 1939 in the journal Elektrische Nachrichtentechnik [5]. In contemporary engineering terms, Raabe dealt with periodic band-limited signals and their reconstruction from pulse amplitude modulated versions. In other words, the band-limited signal is first multiplied by a periodic square wave, an operation that leads to an amplitude modulated pulse train. When the pulses are sufficiently narrow, the pulse amplitude modulated signal becomes, for all practical purposes, a sampled version of the original signal. Fourier analysis of both the pulse train and of the original signal, combined with the use of the superposition principle, lead Raabe to his main conclusions. For details, see Section 3 (particularly Section 3.2). Surprisingly, only two years after its appearance and during World War II, W.R. Bennett cited Raabe's paper in his work on time-division multiplex systems [6]. In turn, Bennett's work was cited by Shannon in [7] as one of his sources of the sampling theorem (cf. Section 4). Raabe's work is remarkably important in connection with the early application of sampling in practice, for several reasons: • Raabe goes beyond theoretical sampling and actually builds a time division multiplex system that allows the simultaneous transmission of several sampled signals over the same transmission line and their separation and recovery at the receiver. • To achieve this goal he deals for the first time with sampling pulses of finite duration (sometimes called “natural sampling”). • He derives the general condition for “distortionless transmission” (sampling at “twice the highest signal frequency”) but he also shows himself in complete command of the band-pass case. • He presents all the details pertaining to the analysis and construction of the electronic circuits needed to build the system. As expected for a work completed in 1939, the circuits are based on vacuum tubes. • He takes into account the impossibility of generating ideal (rectangular) pulses and accounts for the distortions that they necessarily undergo when transmitted through a real line with nonzero resistance, capacitance and inductance. • He discusses the crosstalk that occurs due to the “spreading-out” of the pulses from one channel into the adjacent channels, as the result of the use of non-ideal pulses and transmission lines. • He includes oscillograms of the signals obtained from his prototype. Despite these outstanding characteristics and the historical study by Lüke [3], no in-depth commentary of Raabe's work exists, and the original article of 1939 is no longer readily accessible. One of the purposes of the present paper is to bridge this gap and to discuss the significance and impact of Raabe's work in the early development of sampling and information theory. An English translation of the sections of Raabe's paper that are especially relevant for this is included as an appendix. To understand Raabe's scientific growth it is appropriate to take a look at the exceptional research climate existing in Berlin during his time. Section 2 provides this background information, together with a brief biography of Raabe. Since Raabe's work was completed nearly 70 years ago, it uses a technical language that is not always easy to follow for the contemporary reader. Therefore, in Section 3, we comment on Raabe's approach, its significance from the viewpoint of sampling and the generality of its conclusions. Raabe's condition, its impact and the connection with the Nyquist rate are discussed in Section 4. 2 Herbert Raabe (1909–2004) and his background 2.1 A brief biography of Raabe Herbert P. Raabe (Fig. 1 ) was born on August 15, 1909, in Halle, Germany. He attended the Humboldt Oberrealschule in Zeitz, receiving the graduation certificate in 1929. Subsequently he studied electrical engineering and telecommunications at the Technische Hochschule Berlin (TH Berlin), receiving the Diplom in 1936. In 1937 he became a research assistant and in December 1939 an Oberingenieur at the Chair in Telecommunications of Professors Wilhelm Stäblein (1900–1945) and Karl Küpfmüller (1897–1977), who between 1935 and 1936 had been responsible for the vacant chair in Telecommunications. In 1939 Raabe earned his doctorate (summa cum laude) with the dissertation Untersuchungen an der wechselzeitigen Mehrfachübertragung which appeared in 1939 in the journal Elektrische Nachrichtentechnik [5] and in which he describes the time division multiplexing system discussed in the present paper. The thesis was supervised by Stäblein and Heinrich Fassbender (1884–1970), who had been professor of high-frequency engineering at TH Berlin since 1918. After Stäblein's death, Raabe was put in charge 1 1 For a few weeks only, since Stäblein's died on February 20, 1945, in an air raid, and the TH Berlin was shut down on April 20, 1945. of the chair as well as a section of the Heinrich Hertz Institut. During World War II Raabe developed radar techniques at this institute. He was not reappointed as Oberingenieur at the TH Berlin after the War as he had been a member of the NSDAP (National Socialist German Workers Party). Raabe sent his Erinnerungen (personal recollections) [8] to Prof. P. Noll (Berlin), in a communication dated December 20, 1994. These highlight his time in Berlin up to 1947 and show his practical experiences in signal processing and radar in a new perspective. He speaks of his influences on his profession, and also singles out some of his teachers for special mention. These include three electrical engineers whom we have already met; Fassbender (whose lectures especially appealed to him), Küpfmüller and Stäblein. He also mentions another electrical engineer, Rudolf Franke (1870–1962) who was known as the “Schöpfer der Fernmeldetechnik”; Franke had been a student of Franz Reuleaux. Another of his favourite teachers was the physicist Gustav Hertz (1887–1975), the Nobel Laureate. Küpfmüller had suggested to Raabe a dissertation topic that did not at all appeal to him; it was Stäblein who had proposed multiplex transmission, the topic of his thesis. Raabe also goes into the work of Schreyer (who played a major rôle in engineering circles in South America after World War II) and computer pioneer Konrad Zuse; Section 2.2 discusses Raabe's background in Berlin in more detail. As early as 1931 Raabe worked on radio receiver circuitry and in the Summer of 1934 on signalling equipment for ships at Kiel Harbour. In the Fall of 1939, Wernher von Braun, his good friend, came to Berlin with his assistant Ernst Steinhof to discuss rocket developments. Raabe worked on the steering systems for the A-4 and later the V-2 rockets; he addressed what had been a difficult unsolved problem, connected with their distance and speed. A special recollection was being called by the Luftwaffe to Calais where a radar station wanted to be able to distinguish aircraft from a countermeasure known as Düppel, that is, radar-reflecting metallic strips, also known as “chaff” or “window”. 2 2 The British started to use “window” in July 1943 [9]. Raabe's visit to Calais probably took place shortly after this date. The dimension of the strips was tuned to the radar's signal wavelength. Raabe's reply, in five minutes: change the modulation frequency. In 1944 he was commissioned to instruct interceptor aircraft pilots to distinguish between fighter bombers and chaff. He also considered range deception techniques, and he mentions one device, the Rebok, which transmitted back a received radio impulse after a certain delay. His suggestion was to implement the variable delay 3 3 The basic range deception technique involves sending back an amplified copy of the received radar impulse, and then a delayed, weaker replica. The first signal forces the radar's receiver automatic gain controller to decrease its sensitivity and therefore to ignore the true echo. The receiver then takes the weaker replica as the true echo and detects a “phantom target”. If the delay is gradually increased, the phantom target will appear to be receding. by transmitting an impulse ultrasonically through a water container. The suggestion could not be carried out in practice, as the Berlin institute was destroyed by bombs. In 1947 Raabe was invited by the US Air Force to work as a Technical Consultant. In 1956 he joined the Electronics Division of General Mills/Litton Industries, developing novel radar technologies and electromagnetic counter-measures. From 1966 to 1974 he was employed with the IBM Federal Systems Division. He advised NASA on the design of Microwave Landing System (MLS) for the space shuttle. Even after retirement in 1974 he continued to be very active. In 1989 Raabe was commemorated at Kleinheubach, Germany, upon the 50th anniversary of the publication of his doctoral thesis. Raabe, who was the author of 15 articles and 19 patents, died 4 4 The obituary published in a local newspaper, the Potomac Almanac, in September 15, 2004, is still available at on August 25, 2004, in Potomac, Maryland, where he had resided since 1968. 2.2 The research milieu in Berlin 1930–1940 To understand Raabe's scientific growth it is appropriate to look at the exceptional research climate existing not only at the TH Berlin [10] but in Berlin itself and its industrial firms with their research centres during his time. The heart of the TH Berlin was no doubt their Mechanical Engineering Department, its internationally known professor from 1864 to 1896 being Franz Reuleaux (1829–1905). Born in a suburb of Aachen and regarded as the chief spokesman for German engineers from about 1870 to 1890, Reuleaux [11, pp. 74–75] was considered the founder of modern kinematics as an independent discipline. In this department, two independent major directions developed, Electrical Engineering in 1886, Shipbuilding in 1894. The first to hold a chair in the former was Adolf Slaby (1849–1913). Rudolf Franke (1870–1962) [12], who had a Chair in Telecommunications, was one of the teachers whom Raabe mentions in his recollections [8], along with Stäblein and Küpfmüller. Küpfmüller [13, pp. 96–102] [14], who began working at the renowned Siemens & Halske AG [13,15] in 1921, becoming its director of development and research in 1937 but remaining as Honorary Professor, is known for his seminal work in almost all fields of electrical engineering. He became Full Professor in Danzig at the age of 30. As well as holding a chair at TH Berlin, Stäblein was simultaneously departmental manager of the Heinrich Hertz Institut für Schwingungsforschung (Oscillation and Vibration Institute), founded 1927 by K.W. Wagner (1883–1953) [16] (who was dismissed in 1936 seemingly because of his opposition to Nazism 5 5 It is estimated that between 1100 and 2500 professors of all categories at German universities and scientific academies were dismissed on racial or political grounds during the period 1933–1940 (see [17] and references therein). The fate of 187 mathematicians forced to leave Germany and Austria has been documented in a series of papers by Maximilian Pinl, but no such work appears to have been done for the engineers or other professional classes. ). The fact that Küpfmüller's first position in 1919 was with K.W. Wagner at the “Telegraphen Versuchsanstalt” also confirms the close interaction between these persons. One of Stäblein's assistants was Helmut Schreyer (1912–1985), an engineer at the Institute of Telecommunications. Together they took a hand in advising Konrad Zuse (1910–1995) [18] on the design of his electrical calculating machine, which was in fact the world's first binary digital computer. It was called the Z3 and was completed in 1941. 6 6 The Z3 was never put to use during World War II, unlike the Colossus I, in operation at Bletchley Park by February 1944. However, the Colossus was not an all purpose computer, but instead it was designed to decipher high-level German messages. Built by the engineer Tommy Flowers, with input by the mathematician Max Newman, it was the young Cambridge mathematician Bill Tutte (1917–2002) who brilliantly exploited a transmission error of August 30, 1941, to discover the basic structure of the German Lorenz SZ 40 / 42 encryption machine. In Bletchley Park, Tutte was “the giant on whose shoulders everybody was standing, including Alan Turing” [19]. Tutte's breakthrough lead to the Colossus I (which was followed by nine others). Tutte, who received his doctorate from Cambridge in 1948, then taught at the University of Toronto (one of the authors, P.L.B., attended his topology course there) and since 1962 at Waterloo, has been described as “the leading graph and matroid theorist of his generation” [20]. The Enigma code, the German cipher system, was first broken by Polish mathematicians in 1933, their leaders being Marian Rejewski and Henryk Zygalski. They used information supplied by the French cryptographer Gustave Bertrand, obtained from a spy. In 1939, just before the war, the Poles managed to flee; they gave France (via G. Bertrand) and Britain replicas of the Enigma encoding machine, and disclosed their decoding procedures [21]. These facts were only recognised much later. According to I.J. Good [19], Turing was secretive regarding his sources and the work of the Polish team. The first working models of an all-purpose digital computer devised in the U.S.A., at MIT, Harvard, University of Pennsylvania (ENIAC), Aberdeen Proving Grounds, the Institute of Advanced Study and Caltech, were in operation only at the end of the war. The Harvard Mark I was completed August 1944, the ENIAC February 1946. The driving force in all projects from the late 1920s to the 1940s, was Vannevar Bush (1890–1974; later as chairman of the Office of Scientific Research and Development, or OSRD). Mathematicians involved in the design were Norbert Wiener and John von Neumann [22]. At MIT, Bush was a great mentor of Shannon, supervising his prizewinning master and doctoral thesis. Such was the research environment while Raabe was working on his thesis, the main ideas of which are discussed in the next section. 3 Raabe's approach and results 3.1 The time-division multiplexing problem in telephony To the engineer, the word “multiplexing” immediately suggests the simultaneous (or apparently simultaneous) transmission of multiple signals through the same wire or channel, and their recovery at the receiving end. The two simplest ways of achieving it are time division and frequency division multiplexing. In the case of frequency division multiplexing, the frequency band available for transmission is divided into intervals, called sub-bands. Each signal to be transmitted is assigned one of the sub-bands, through a process called modulation. A discussion of some pioneering developments related to frequency-division multiplexing can be found in [27,28]. Time division multiplexing, as the name suggests, is based on time sharing. The period of time available for the transmission is divided into intervals, and each transmitter is assigned one such interval in turn. The duration of each interval is typically very small compared with the duration of the messages, so that to an observer the multiple transmissions appear to be happening simultaneously. Raabe deals only with time division multiplexing. At the time he wrote (Figs. 2 and 3 ), time division multiplexing had been applied to telegraphy [29], and Raabe mentions two telegraph multiplexing systems: the Baudot 8 8 Jean-Maurice-Émile Baudot (1845–1903), born in Magneux, France, September 11, 1845. A telegraph engineer and one of the pioneers of telecommunications, he worked in the development of fast telegraphy, and invented the Baudot system for simultaneous transmission of several signals over the same wire (Fig. 3). The Baudot time division multiplexing system followed previous work by F.C. Bakewell (1848), A.V. Newton (1851), M.B. Farmer (1853) and especially B. Meyer (1870). Baudot also invented the Baudot code, a predecessor of the ASCII code. The term “baud”, a measure of the number of symbols transmitted per second, is named after him. system, and the Delany 9 9 Patrick Bernard Delany (1845–1924) was born in King's County, Ireland, on January 28, 1845, and moved to the United States in 1854. By the age of 16 he was already an accomplished telegraphist and became chief operator of the Franklin Telegraph Company, assistant general superintendent of the Southern and Atlantic Telegraph Company and superintendent of the Automatic Telegraph Company. He left telegraphy and became a newspaper correspondent at Washington and subsequently editor of Old Commonwealth, Harrisonburg, Virginia. From 1880 onwards he turned his attention to inventing. He obtained over one hundred patents, mostly related to telegraphy. He developed a multiplexing system which built on previous work by P. LaCour of Copenhagen. The Delany system had advantages over the Baudot system, and impressed W.H. Preece, FRS, [30], being adopted by the British post-office. For his work in high speed and synchronous telegraphy, the Franklin Institut awarded Delany the John Scott Medal in 1885 and the Elliot Cresson Medal in 1886 and 1896. system. In fact, the opening sentences and his first diagram refer to the idea that underlies time division multiplexing: Two synchronised rotating switches connect several transmitters to an equal number of receivers. After connecting the transmitter 1 to the corresponding receiver throughout a certain interval, the switch moves to the next position and connects the transmitter and receiver 2 for another interval of the same duration and so on until the connection of the last transmitter and receiver. Afterwards the sequence starts again, leading once more to the connection of the transmitter and receiver 1 and so on cyclically. The mathematical model that describes the multiplexing of any finite number of signals is simple. Assuming as an example that there are three channels, the relevant signals would be related as shown in the diagram in Fig. 4 . The multiplexing system can be regarded as a multi-channel system, with inputs x 1 ( t ) , x 2 ( t ) and x 3 ( t ) and one output m ( t ) given by m ( t ) = ∑ i = 1 3 s i ( t ) x i ( t ) . The extension to any finite number of channels should be clear. The multiplexed signal m ( t ) would be transmitted to the receiver, where the separation of x 1 ( t ) , x 2 ( t ) and x 3 ( t ) from the input m ( t ) takes place. The receiver is illustrated in the diagram of Fig. 5 . It is again a multi-channel system that takes m ( t ) as the input and ideally would yield x 1 ( t ) , x 2 ( t ) and x 3 ( t ) as outputs. The existence of the operator H, which reconstructs the signals x i ( t ) from s i ( t ) m ( t ) , cannot be taken for granted due to the apparent loss of information in the process. As Raabe writes, ( … ) those sections of the function which fall within the instants of switching will not be transmitted. The received signal is therefore different from the transmitted one. Raabe points out that the Delany multiplexing system was intended for telegraphy, and that its application to telephony requires a “totally different technical setup”. In fact it requires a new theoretical approach as well, which Raabe provides in the first part of his paper. He gives a condition that guarantees that there is no “distortion”, that is, each of the input (multiplexed) signals can be recovered (theoretically) without any error. The condition is expressed, as we will soon find, in terms of the spectrum of the signals that are to be multiplexed and in terms of the sampling frequency, that is, the rate at which each particular channel is connected to the multiplexing system, which is also given by the frequency of any of the square waves s 1 ( t ) , s 2 ( t ) or s 3 ( t ) . The “sections of the function” mentioned by Raabe could as well be called “local averages” or “samples”, since they are determined by the product of the function by square waves such as s 1 ( t ) , s 2 ( t ) and s 3 ( t ) in our example. In a typical application, the width of the pulses would be small when compared to the sampling period. In Raabe's Fig. A8 the pulses are relatively wide, but for example in his Fig. A5 they are so narrow that they appear as “line needles”. A condition that ensures that each multiplexed signal is recovered without distortion means, under Raabe's framework, that each signal can be recovered from its “samples”. And since Raabe is interested in building the system, he cannot merely state a condition for transmission without distortion—he has to describe a practical recovery procedure as well. In other words, he determines a practical approximation to the reconstruction operator H. 3.2 Raabe's condition for distortionless transmission To understand Raabe's point of view, it is necessary to obtain the Fourier expansion of the square waves that will be multiplied by the signals to be multiplexed. Any such square wave, s ( t ) , say, can be translated at will without loss of generality, and he translates it so that it becomes an even function (see his Fig. A3). The Fourier series is given by his equation (3), repeated here for convenience: s ( t ) = k 2 π y m + ∑ n = 1 ∞ ( ‐ 1 ) n 2 n π y m sin nk 2 cos n ω 1 t . Here, y m is the height of each pulse, ω 1 is the angular sampling frequency, and k / ω 1 is the width of the pulse. In electrical engineering, the ratio of the width of the pulse to the period of the wave is usually called the duty cycle. We see thus that Raabe is considering a square wave of frequency ω 1 and duty cycle k / 2 π . His parameter k, the range of which is ( 0 , 2 π ) , corresponds to what he calls “the channel width”, “expressed in terms of phase”. The received signal will be the product of the square wave s ( t ) and the signal that needs to be transmitted, denoted by f ( t ) . For Raabe, the product r ( t ) = s ( t ) f ( t ) is “the modulated signal”, the square wave s ( t ) is “the unmodulated signal”, and the signal f ( t ) is “the modulating signal”. This terminology is of course borrowed from modulation theory. To obtain an amplitude modulated signal, one multiplies a carrier s ( t ) = sin ( ω t ) by some modulating signal f ( t ) , that is, one performs r ( t ) = s ( t ) f ( t ) . In other words, the amplitude of the sinusoid sin ( ω t ) is modulated according to the amplitude of f ( t ) . Raabe is using a square wave instead of the usual sinusoidal carrier; but the amplitude of this square wave is modulated by f ( t ) , as in the standard amplitude modulation scheme. His terminology is, in this sense, quite natural. Strictly speaking, the form of amplitude modulation expressed by r ( t ) = s ( t ) f ( t ) is best described as suppressed carrier amplitude modulation, whereas amplitude modulation in general would obey r ( t ) = s ( t ) [ α + β f ( t ) ] for some nonzero constants α and β . Note the term α s ( t ) , proportional to the carrier, which is absent in the case that we have been discussing. Raabe uses the word grenzmoduliert to refer to the suppressed carrier amplitude modulation scheme (see the footnote on p. 216 of his paper). To understand the effect of the modulating signal f ( t ) on the square wave s ( t ) , Raabe also expands f ( t ) in a Fourier series, and investigates the effect of the general term of this Fourier series on each frequency of the square wave. So the problem is reduced to that of understanding products of square waves and sinusoids, as in his Fig. A8. The result for a more general f ( t ) follows by superposition. The square wave had been decomposed in a Fourier series as well. And, as he writes ( … ) The modulation of a carrier representable as a Fourier series is equivalent to modulating each single frequency of the whole spectrum on its own. Raabe's next step is to assume that the signal to transmit, also called the modulating signal, is simply cos ( m ω 1 t ) , where m is a real number. Multiplication of this signal by the Fourier series of the square wave s ( t ) yields the received signal r ( t ) : (A) r ( t ) = k 2 π y m cos m ω 1 t + ∑ n = 1 ∞ ( ‐ 1 ) n 1 n π y m sin nk 2 [ cos ( n ‐ m ) ω 1 t + cos ( n + m ) ω 1 t ] . Raabe in fact multiplies by sin ( m ω 1 t + ψ ) , as shown in his equation (15), and after a few elementary manipulations reaches his equation (17). He later sets ψ = π / 2 to simplify the computations, and also because for the study of “energy-type distributions of the receiver spectrum” the phase angle ψ is of no real interest. He then reaches (A), which is essentially his equation (20). He notes that the received signal r ( t ) includes the transmitted signal, which has replaced the “direct voltage term”, namely k 2 π y m cos m ω 1 t . We will now consider the remaining terms, following Raabe's reasoning (check for example his Fig. A9). The frequencies appearing in r ( t ) are depicted in our Fig. 6 . Essentially, Raabe argues that to avoid ambiguity m has to satisfy m < 1 ‐ m , that is, m < 1 / 2 . In other words, the transmitted frequency must be below ω 1 / 2 , that is, one-half the sampling frequency. The condition guarantees that the spectral line marked m in the diagram (the one that replaced the “direct voltage term”) stays to the left of the “complementary frequency” 1 ‐ m , which in the context of amplitude modulation is called the “lower sideband of the first harmonic”. For signals consisting of a superposition of terms with different frequencies, the distortion can be avoided if all the frequencies are below one-half the sampling rate. This is how Raabe puts it: ( … ) the sampling frequency is determined by the range of signal frequencies. If these are kept below half of the sampling frequency, all of the noise frequencies above this limit can be kept away from the receiver by a low-pass filter. The transmission of a signal may thus be completely distortionless, if the sampling frequency is twice the highest signal frequency. The upper limitation of the signal frequencies is therefore a vital condition of distortionless transmission by time division multiplex transmission. This paragraph, also quoted by Lüke [3], summarises what has been called “Raabe's condition” (see Section 4 for further discussion). Note that the argument that lead Raabe to this statement was not merely qualitative, 10 10 Meijering (2002) writes [31, p. 325] “in more implicit verbal form, [the sampling theorem] had also been described in the German literature by Raabe”. Raabe's statement is a verbal summary of his findings for low-pass signals, but follows from the Fourier analysis of the sampled signal. but based on the analysis of the Fourier spectrum of the product of the modulating square wave and the signal. Raabe's conclusion has a legitimate mathematical basis, valid for the class of signals he considered. Note that Raabe regards the frequencies that appear above one-half of the sampling frequency as “noise frequencies”. Today, they would be called “aliasing terms”. Also recall that “distortionless transmission by time division multiplex” implies the recovery of each signal from its samples (or sections), in the sense previously discussed. At this point, it is worthwhile to look at some of the oscillograms obtained by Raabe [5, pp. 226–227], which are reproduced in Fig. 7 . They show the unmodulated signal (a square wave) and its product with three sinusoids of different frequencies. In case (b) the frequency of the sinusoid is less than one-half the frequency of the unmodulated signal ( 1 6 of that frequency, as can be found from the figure). The square wave also has a small duty cycle, so that the result resembles the acquisition of six samples per period of the sinusoid. The result in case (c) is very similar, but there is aliasing. The frequency of the sinusoid is above one-half the frequency of the unmodulated signal ( 5 6 of that frequency, as follows from the figure). This corresponds to the smallest alias frequency, the “lower sideband of the first harmonic”. In modern sampling terms, the frequency of the sinusoid in (b) is ω 0 , the sampling frequency (the frequency of the square wave) is ω s and ω 0 / ω s = 1 6 . The alias frequency in (c) would then be ω s ‐ ω 0 and of course ( ω s ‐ ω 0 ) / ω s = 5 6 as in Raabe's example (c). Raabe's oscillogram (d) illustrates the use of square waves of larger duty cycle, and how they retain segments of the signal that is multiplied by them. 3.3 Raabe's condition in the band-pass case Raabe realises that the reconstruction of the signal can be accomplished by a “low-pass filter”, but he does not stop here. He notes that sampling at “twice the highest signal frequency” is not always necessary, and that the sampling frequency can be decreased if the spectrum of the transmitted signal is of the band-pass type. Raabe states that “special conditions apply when the frequency range is limited to an octave”, in which case ( … ) one can lay down the sampling frequency onto the upper frequency limit, and the noise frequencies remain partly above the useful range, and partly, as in the case of the complementary frequency, below. The value “one octave” is of course correct. It follows from Fig. 6 (or Raabe's Fig. A9) that for the lower “noise frequency” 1 ‐ m to be below the transmitted frequency m, the following conditions must hold: 1 ‐ m > 0 , 1 ‐ m < m . This restricts the transmitted frequencies to the range implied by 1 2 < m < 1 , that is, the highest signal frequency must be below ω 1 and the lowest above ω 1 / 2 , meaning that the bandwidth of the signal should be limited to one octave. Raabe understands that “frequencies above the sampling frequency can also be transmitted free from distortion, but the relative range of frequencies shrinks more and more”. In fact, as it is well known today, the minimum sampling density is determined by the bandwidth of the signal and not necessarily by its highest frequency. The discussion would not be complete without mentioning the modifications that must be made to the recovery procedure in the band-pass case. Raabe writes that ( … ) one has to keep away from the receiver those noise frequencies lying outside of each section by a band pass filter. From his perspective of circuit design, the only change necessary is the replacement of the low-pass filter by a band-pass filter. 3.4 Admissible functions and generalised sampling Raabe's main mathematical tool is the Fourier series. The square wave needed by the multiplexing system is expanded in a Fourier series, the fundamental frequency of which is the sampling frequency. Similarly, the signal to be transmitted is also expanded in a Fourier series. The effect of the multiplication of the Fourier series is analysed, term by term, and the main results follow. Raabe's conclusions apply to signals that can be expressed as a linear combination of sinusoidal terms (or complex exponentials), the frequencies of which do not exceed one-half of the sampling frequency. The admissible functions include all band-limited periodic functions or trigonometric polynomials f ( t ) = ∑ k = ‐ M N c k e 2 π ikt / T but not band-limited square-integrable (finite-energy) signals, for example. However, for the purposes of using Raabe's time division multiplexing system this is not a restriction. The system would be able to handle signals of arbitrarily large but finite duration. 11 11 The sampling theorem with the sinc function for functions of finite duration was first established by the mathematician Ch. de la Vallée Poussin [32] in 1908; for a discussion of his contribution and its influence see [33]. The sampling expansion for trigonometric polynomials is in fact due to Euler, who discussed it more than once; so did Cauchy. See [34] for details about the method used by Euler to derive expansions such as cos vt = sin π t π 1 t + 2 t ∑ n = 1 ∞ cos vn ( ‐ 1 ) n t 2 ‐ n 2 , ( | v | ≤ π ) and other related historical information. Raabe's practical perspective is reflected in the way he deals with the reconstruction problem. After determining the aliasing terms, the reconstruction problem is essentially solved: The separation of the aliased terms or “noise frequencies” from the signal frequencies can be achieved by using a linear filter. The next step is the design of a low-pass or perhaps a band-pass filter and the matter is closed. His strong practical view may help to understand why he did not explicitly state a reconstruction formula based on the ideal low-pass filter, introduced by Küpfmüller and known as “Küpfmüller-Tiefpass” in the German literature. Instead of obtaining a theoretical reconstruction formula, for which he probably felt very little need, Raabe obtains a real reconstructed signal. In fact, it is worthwhile to discuss the connection between the system that Raabe built and generalised sampling. 12 12 Generalised sampling theory was developed at Aachen from 1977 onwards. It was first studied in the doctoral dissertation of Splettstößer [35], continued by Stens [36], Ries–Stens [37] and Butzer, Engels et al. [38]; overview papers are [39–41]. Let f ( t ) be one of the input signals. The corresponding sampled signal is obtained by multiplying f ( t ) by a square wave s ( t ) , which can be expressed as a sum of pulses p ( t ) . Hence, assuming for simplicity a unitary sampling period, we have f ( t ) s ( t ) = f ( t ) ∑ n p ( t ‐ n ) . Assume that the “channel width” is small, so that the square waves look like “line needles”. Then the sampled signal is approximately given by g ( t ) = ∑ n f ( n ) p ( t ‐ n ) . Consider now the lowpass filter implemented by Raabe. Let its response to a pulse p ( t ) be denoted by h ( t ) . The reconstructed signal obtained using Raabe's system can then be written as ∑ n f ( n ) h ( t ‐ n ) . There are two main differences to the classical sampling theorem: the sinc kernel, the Fourier transform of the ideal lowpass filter, 13 13 It is indeed surprising that Raabe nowhere in his thesis mentions the sinc function explicitly, which had been defined by his teacher Küpfmüller. However, it should be kept in mind that the ideal lowpass filter, and hence the sinc function, cannot be implemented. Therefore, it could not ever become part of the multiplexing system that Raabe was trying to design and build. sinc ( t ) ≔ sin π t π t , has been replaced by the function h ( t ) , the pulse response of the filter used in the implementation; and there are only finitely many samples f ( n ) . Both differences would necessarily occur in any practical realisation of sampling. The classical sampling theorem with the sinc kernel f ( t ) = ∑ n = ‐ ∞ ∞ f ( n ) sinc ( t ‐ n ) is not to be found explicitly in Raabe's paper. However, instead of multiplying f ( t ) = cos ( m ω 1 t ) , 0 < m < 1 / 2 , by the Fourier series expansion of the square wave in Raabe's Fig. A3, which leads to (A) or Raabe's equation (20), one could obtain a sampling theorem by multiplying f ( t ) by the sum of translated rect functions that describes the square wave itself, formally letting the pulse widths k / ω 1 decrease to zero to obtain the “line needles” mentioned by Raabe, and then low-pass filtering the result. The more general result in which f ( t ) is a linear combination of sines and cosines subject to the same frequency limitation would follow by superposition. Although these steps are not to be found explicitly in Raabe's paper, it is a reasonable inference that in view of Raabe's approach and results he was aware of more general results, but did not state anything in further generality because his interests were in more practical directions. Raabe might have felt little need for the sinc reconstruction formula because he could not implement it, nor did it describe the system he built. The formula would also fail to account for sources of error of which he was well aware and which he analyses. Examples are the effect of the rectangular pulses, and the distortions that they necessarily undergo when transmitted through a real line with nonzero resistance, capacitance and inductance as well as the crosstalk that occurs due to the “spreading-out” of the pulses from one channel into the adjacent channels, due to the nonideal transmission lines. Formula (A), which is Raabe's equation (20), is a more useful approximation to the behaviour of the system, as it expresses “the frequency spectrum of the modulated signal”, that is, the spectrum of the sampled signal. For example, at the end of Section 4, Raabe uses the second term of (A) to identify the effect of using “small channel widths k”, that is, pulses of small but finite duration: the attenuation by a factor of sin ( k / 2 ) / ( k / 2 ) , which as he notes approaches 1 as k approaches zero. 4 Raabe's condition and the Nyquist rate Raabe's condition relates distortionless transmission to the signal spectrum and sampling frequency, for both low-pass and band-pass spectra (cf. Sections 3.2 and 3.3 and the translation in the Appendix). It is difficult to determine exactly how the notice of Raabe's work spread (or failed to spread) through the scientific community at the time, mainly in Germany and in the United States. This section is a start toward this, and provides background material that helps to understand Raabe's condition, its context and impact, and the connection with the so-called “Nyquist rate”. 4.1 Background on Raabe's condition In an interesting letter that he wrote to Lüke 14 14 Prof. Lüke carried on an extensive correspondence with Dr. Raabe from October 5, 1978, onwards. In a footnote attached to Nyquist's 17 17 Harry Nyquist was born on February 7 1889 in Nilsby, Sweden. He emigrated to America, attended the University of North Dakota, Grand Forks, from 1912 to 1915, and received the B.S. and M.S. degrees in electrical engineering in 1914 and 1915, respectively. He attended Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut, from 1915 to 1917, and was awarded the Ph.D. degree in 1917. Kelly award in 1961. He passed away on April 4, 1976. name, Shannon cites Nyquist's famous paper on telegraphy [46] and Bennett's paper on time division multiplex systems [6], which cites Raabe. We shall briefly discuss both works and the connection with Raabe's work and its impact. Nyquist's classical papers of 1924 and 1928 on telegraphy [47,46] show a thorough understanding of the connection between signalling speed, number of bits per symbol and bandwidth. Nyquist also fully understood intersymbol interference and how to avoid it. These are landmark achievements, for which he is justly remembered. However, an explicit formulation of the sampling theorem cannot be found in his works, and it would take some more time to appear in the engineering literature. Nyquist did establish that “the speed with which intelligence can be transmitted” increases linearly with the line speed or the number of symbols that can be transmitted per unit time, and linearly with log m or the number of bits per symbol; and his view of telegraphy is strikingly modern and contains key ideas underlying digital communication systems such as PCM, which would be discussed two decades later. PCM was the subject of the important paper of 1948 by Oliver, Pierce and Shannon [48]. The paper connected key concepts such as sampling, quantisation, coding and channel capacity. Its Appendix I contains a proof of the sampling theorem (along the lines given in [7]), but more importantly it described the essence of the problem in simple terms, which would appeal strongly to the engineering audience: To reconstruct the signal it is merely necessary to generate from each sample a proportional impulse, and to pass this regularly spaced series of impulses through an ideal low-pass filter of cutoff frequency W 0 . The output of this filter will then be (except for an overall time delay and possibly a constant of proportionality) identical to the input signal. Since the response of an ideal lowpass filter to an impulse is a sin x / x pulse, and since the total output is the linear sum of the responses to all inputs, this method of reconstruction is simply the physical embodiment of [the sampling theorem]. The masterful exposition of Oliver, Pierce and Shannon represents a synthesis of work that had its origin in Nyquist and the earlier precursors of telegraphy and culminated in Shannon's theory of communication. As the advantages of PCM started to be recognised, the importance of Nyquist's legacy became clear. Oliver, Pierce and Shannon wrote: If it surprises the reader to find that 2 W 0 T pieces of data will describe a continuous function completely over the interval T, it should be remembered that the 2 W 0 T coefficients of the sine and cosine terms of a Fourier series do just this, if, as we have assumed, the function contains no frequencies higher than W 0 . The approach of Nyquist (as that of Raabe) was of course firmly based on the analysis of the Fourier series of periodic signals, as these lines bring to mind. It is therefore not surprising what Shannon wrote when he discussed the sampling theorem in his article of 1949 [7]: Nyquist pointed out the fundamental importance of the time interval 1 / 2 W seconds in connection with telegraphy, and we will call this the Nyquist interval corresponding to the band. Shannon's “crisp statement and proof of the sampling theorem”, as Verdú put it [49, p. 2063], was instrumental in popularising sampling in the engineering mainstream, as was his reference to Nyquist. The expressions “Nyquist interval” or “Nyquist rate”, applied in reference to band-limited signals, the sampling theorem and PCM, very likely had their origin here, and spread rapidly as the enormous impact of Shannon's work began to be felt. 4.3 Bennett and Raabe Let us now return to Bennett's paper [6], also mentioned by Shannon, who writes that in it “a result similar to [the sampling theorem] is established, but on a steady-state basis.” And indeed the second section of [6], entitled “General Theory”, presents an approach to time-division multiplex systems. It is based on the Fourier series expansion of the waveform that represents the “switching process” (which occurs at what we would now call the sampling frequency). The action of the switching process on the input signal of the j th channel, E j ( t ) = E j e i ω j t , causes “upper and lower side frequencies from the signal on each harmonic of the switching frequency”—hence on each harmonic of the sampling frequency. After a comparison with amplitude modulation, Bennett goes on to consider the effect of a transmission line with a certain impedance and the rôle of the receiver. He reaches the conclusion that it is possible to separate the frequencies involved in the switching from that of the original signal, provided that ω j < q / 2 (his Eq. (11), p. 203), where q is the sampling frequency—the usual “Nyquist rate” condition. It is interesting to compare Bennett's and Raabe's work. Bennett's considers, unlike Raabe's, a general “switching function”; Raabe specifically considers the switching function in his Fig. A3 and its Fourier series expansion (see also our Section 3.2), but goes on to consider the band-pass case as well. Both Bennett and Raabe depend on the Fourier series, both consider periodic input signals, both compare the effects of switching with those of amplitude modulation, and both papers can be considered as containing sampling results on a “steady-state basis”, as Shannon wrote. Bennett does not refer directly to Raabe in his “General Theory” section, nor anywhere else in the paper. Raabe's paper is listed only at the end, included in a group of three “Further References”. Because the title of Raabe's paper is in German and no hints concerning its content are given, the relevance of Raabe's work for sampling or even time-division multiplex systems would not be clear at all to the readers of Bennett's paper. These reasons and the natural difficulty in obtaining copies of the work during the war certainly did not help to direct attention to Raabe's work immediately after its appearance (and before the appearance of Shannon's works of 1948 and 1949). 4.4 Raabe's work after 1948 After the war and the publication of Shannon's works [50,7] the theoretical contributions present in Raabe's work, written in German and published in a German journal, had even fewer chances of being noticed. Almost two decades after the publication of Raabe's paper, the 1958 dissertation of Schüssler [51] on the sampling theorem at RWTH Aachen does not refer to Raabe but explicitly only to Shannon (on p. 6 of the dissertation). However, such a proof is, surprisingly, not to be found in Kotel’nikov's paper [42]. 5 Conclusion There are convincing grounds for giving Raabe credit for discovering the minimum sampling rate for distortionless transmission, independently of Kotel’nikov. He sought a condition to prevent interference in a multiplexing system, and found from the analysis of the system that in the low-pass case the transmitted frequencies must be less than one-half the sampling frequency. He also gave, for the first time, the condition for the band-pass case. It turns out that his conclusions hold in more general contexts, but he formulated them in this setting, one decade before Shannon named the condition after Nyquist, and deserves credit for that. Why was the impact of Raabe's work not more widely felt? In this article we have suggested several reasons. His thesis, written in German and published in a German journal, appeared just before World War II, a period unfavourable to the quick dissemination of knowledge. During the war Raabe worked on radar, and after it he moved to the USA where he began working in other areas. By that time Shannon's work had appeared in the USA and its enormous impact was being felt. In engineering circles, the sampling theorem became firmly associated with Shannon (and Nyquist, see Section 4), although Shannon himself clearly acknowledged that sampling was “common knowledge in the communication art” [50] and cited Bennett [6], who in turn cited Raabe. However, for the reasons explained in Section 4, this was unlikely to attract attention to Raabe's work. Even in Germany, the contributions of Küpfmüller seem to have been more widely known than those of Raabe, a former student at his Chair in TH Berlin. Schüssler's doctoral dissertation of 1958 on the sampling theorem at RWTH Aachen [51] does not mention Raabe. Although Schüssler and Lüke had both been students of the same supervisor (V. Aschoff), it was Lüke [2,3]) who drew attention to Raabe's work; but that was more than 40 years later. Finally, it must be noted that Raabe's thesis contained not only the theory outlined in Section 3, but also additional material, such as circuit diagrams and pictures of the signals, all related to his main goal, the implementation of the multiplexing system. The term “sampling” is not mentioned in the title (nor in the title of Bennett's paper), and the relevance of the work to sampling theory is not immediately obvious. It is quite possible that the theoretical analysis underlying the multiplexing system was overlooked by readers potentially interested in it. As the implementation of the multiplexing system grew obsolete, the chances of someone noting the theoretical contributions became even smaller. By the time Shannon stated and proved the sampling theorem a number of mathematicians and engineers had contributed to sampling. Raabe's work possesses, however, one characteristic that distinguishes it from all others: at a time when the principles underlying sampling and multiplexing were still unclear and in the process of being developed, he managed not only to grasp the essentials of the problem, but to build and test a system that carried the idea to practice. The engineering aspects of his work and its strong practical perspective are indeed outstanding. A.1 Introduction By definition, time division multiplexing is the transmission of several signals on a transmission line, whereby periodically successive short term sections from the signals are connected to the transmission line, as depicted in Fig. A1 . At the transmitter end the signals of the transmitters S 1 , S 2 , … will be switched over a distributor, V s , to the transmission line L. At the other end of the line another distributor, V e , which rotates synchronously with the distributor V s , connects the signals to the different receivers E 1 , E 2 , … . The purpose of this process is a better utilisation of the transmission line. The connection of a transmitter with its accompanying receiver is termed a channel. A transmission system operates therefore with as many channels as connections can be established through the transmission line. The “channel width” is the duration of a connection between a transmitter and its accompanying receiver within one switching period of the multiplex-transmission, expressed in terms of phase. Over and again many inventors have been involved in the development and improvement of the time division multiplex-transmission, but so far a practical realisation in telephony remains unknown. On the other hand theoretical dissertations which deal in detail with the transmission problem are so far unknown. Therefore the goal of this paper is to fill this gap as well as to develop a test installation by which the theoretical result could be verified. One distinguishes between two different systems of time division multiplex transmission. 1. The Baudot system. The function to transmit over one channel must be constrained to fit within the time interval alloted to the channel. If that is the case, the transmitted signal reaches the receiver undistorted. The application of the Baudot system is limited by the need to employ symbols of equal duration, repeated periodically. The system has the advantage of allowing the line to be used to its full potential, despite the speed limitations imposed by manual operation of the telegraphy keys. 2. The Delany system. Except for a restriction concerning its highest frequency, the function to transmit is arbitrary. As a result, the system would be able to deal with telegraphy or telephony signals. However, the segments of the transmitted function that fall outside the alloted time intervals will not be transmitted. The received signal will therefore differ from the transmitted one. The system of Delany is intended for telegraphy only; the idea of extending it to telephony is basically not new, but it requires a totally different technical setup. The present paper deals exclusively with the Delany system. A.2 Theory A.2.1 The mathematical formulation of the distortions The function depicted in Fig. A2 (a) shall be transmitted in the time division multiplex transmission mode. The connection will be established via the distributors with period τ 1 for the duration of the channel width k / ω 1 , according to Fig. A2(b), such that the received function y e ( t ) proceeds as depicted in Fig. A2(c). The transmitted function is representable in the form (1) y s ( t ) = y 0 + ∑ y i sin ( ω i t + ψ i ) , 0 < ω i < ω g , (1a) y s ( t ) = y 0 + M ( t ) . Here y s ( t ) describes the voltage, where y 0 is a direct voltage and M ( t ) = ∑ y i sin ( ω i t + ψ i ) is the sum of all existing alternating voltages with amplitude y i , angular frequency ω i and zero-phase angle ψ i , where ω i shall remain below a limit ω g . This expression represents the actual transmitted function and subsequently will be called “modulating function”. The received function can be put in the form (2) y e ( t ) = ay 0 + b ∑ y i sin ( ω i t + ψ i ) + ∑ y z sin ( ω z t + ψ z ) , (2a) y e ( t ) = ay 0 + bM ( t ) + V ( t ) . If now y e ( t ) is regarded as a voltage, the constant a represents the attenuation factor of the direct voltage element, whereas the constant b is the attenuation factor of the modulating function. Since one cannot expect that the attenuation of the modulating oscillations is frequency independent, one has to expect the occurrence of modulating oscillations in the expression ∑ y z sin ( ω z t + ψ z ) , which also includes all other distortions. In this way, the normally used terms of linear and non-linear distortions have been replaced by a more general concept. A.2.5 The ranges of transmission and the selection of the sampling frequency For the demonstrated conditions of transmission the sampling frequency is determined by the range of signal frequencies. If these are kept below half of the sampling frequency, all of the noise frequencies above this limit can be kept away from the receiver by a low-pass filter. The transmission of a signal may thus be completely distortionless, if the sampling frequency is twice the highest signal frequency. The upper limitation of the signal frequencies is therefore a vital condition of distortionless transmission by time division multiplex transmission. Special conditions apply when the frequency range of a signal is limited to an octave. Then one can lay down the sampling frequency onto the upper frequency limit, and the noise frequencies remain partly above the useful range, and partly, as in the case of complementary frequency, below. Theoretically, frequencies above the sampling frequency can also be transmitted free from distortion, but the relative range of frequencies shrinks more and more. Fig. A10 conveys a general overview. There all frequencies of the receiver function are displayed as functions of the frequency of the modulating oscillation. One recognises that all sections between the points 0 , 1 , 2 … can be covered by the modulation frequency; one only has to keep away from the receiver those noise frequencies lying outside of each section by a band pass filter. doc_title: Trading-off matrix size and matrix structure: Handling Toeplitz equations by embedding on a larger circulant set
doc_abstract: This paper explores a seemingly counter-intuitive idea: the possibility of accelerating the solution of certain linear equations by adding even more equations to the problem. The basic insight is to trade-off problem size by problem structure. We test this idea on Toeplitz equations, in which case the expense of a larger set of equations easily leads to circulant structure. The idea leads to a very simple iterative algorithm, which works for a certain class of Toeplitz matrices, each iteration requiring only two circular convolutions. In the symmetric definite case, numerical experiments show that the method can compete with the preconditioned conjugate gradient method (PCG), which achieves O(nlogn) performance. Because the iteration does not converge for all Toeplitz matrices, we give necessary and sufficient conditions to ensure convergence (for not necessarily symmetric matrices), and suggest an efficient convergence test. In the positive definite case we determine the value of the free parameter of the circulant that leads to the fastest convergence, as well as the corresponding value for the spectral radius of the iteration matrix. Although the usefulness of the proposed iteration is limited in the case of ill-conditioned matrices, we believe that the results show that the problem size/problem structure trade-off deserves further study. © 2010 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

All rights reserved. 1. Introduction There are many problems that lead to Toeplitz equations, and many methods for solving them. Levinson’s algorithm solves n Toeplitz equations in O(n 2 ) flops [1]. Even the inverse of a Toeplitz can be computed in O(n 2 ) flops, using the Trench method [1]. Many variants of these methods have been introduced [2], including a number of methods that can handle Toeplitz matrices with singular submatrices [3,4]. Eﬃcient algorithms suited for rationally generated matrices have also been given [5,6]. Quadratic inversion formulas for matrices “close” to Toeplitz have been given [7,8]. A more general approach, described in [9], has lead to O(n 2 ) algorithms for a class of matrices with recursive structure. This includes Toeplitz, Hankel and other matrices. Block–Toeplitz matrices with Toeplitz entries are also studied in [10]. The fast solver proposed in [11], based on a modified QR algorithm, is backward stable and can be applied to a class of nonsymmetric Toeplitz-like matrices. It also explores displacement structure (see [12] for a review). There are also O(nlog 2 n) methods. The one in [13] applies to matrices of low displacement rank, the method in [14] is based on Padé approximation, and Ref. [15] uses a generalized Schur algorithm and applies to real positive definite Toeplitz ✩ Some of the results contained in this work were presented at the 109th Annual Meeting of the American Mathematical Society, Baltimore, MD, January 2003, and in the SampTA-03, Strobl, Austria, May 2003. * Corresponding author. The method described in [16] uses real trigonometric transformations and solves symmetric Toeplitz equations with complexity O(nlog 2 n). Iterative approaches based on Newton’s method [17,18] have also been reported. Hermitian positive definite Toeplitz equations can be solved using the preconditioned conjugate gradient (PCG) method [19,20], implementing the matrix-vector products using the FFT. Adequate preconditioning [21–26] may lead to O(nlogn) performance. This paper introduces a new idea for solving linear equations: the idea of embedding the original matrix in a larger but more structured matrix. The size of the problem increases, but the more regular structure may allow a net performance gain. We test the concept on Toeplitz equations, and show that the embedding of the Toeplitz matrix in a circulant leads to an eﬃcient and extremely simple iterative algorithm, that can under certain conditions compete with PCG. In Section 2 we recall some theoretical facts regarding circulant and Toeplitz matrices, that will be used in the rest of the paper. The proposed method is described in Section 3, and its convergence is analyzed in Section 4. Section 5 is concerned with the very important problem of positive definite Toeplitz systems. For these matrices, we provide several theorems which justify the convergence of the algorithm. Finally, some experimental results are shown. Although the usefulness of the proposed iteration is limited in the case of ill-conditioned matrices, we believe that the results show that the problem size/problem structure trade-off has potential, and deserves further study. 2. Preliminaries Let us recall some results about Toeplitz and circulant matrices. If C is a circulant matrix of order 2n, it is known that its eigenvalues are {λ i (C)} 0lessorequalslanti<2n , where λ i (C) is the ith element of the discrete Fourier transform (DFT) of the first row of C. By expressing the DFT of length 2n as two DFTs of length n, it is shown in [27] that the eigenvalues of T + S are {λ 2i (C)} 0lessorequalslanti<n , and those of T − S are {λ 2i+1 (C)} 0lessorequalslanti<n . The matrix-vector products are 2n-dimensional circular convolutions that can be performed in O(nlogn) flops using standard FFT or fast convolution algorithms. The FFT of the first column of C needs to be computed only once, and imme- diately determines the FFT of the first column of C −1 . Both steps (1) and (2) of the algorithm require one FFT and one IFFT of (at least) 2n points, and hence O(nlogn) flops. More specific speedups are possible but will not be discussed for brevity (for example, it is well known that the bit-reversal stages can be avoided by properly selecting the FFT and IFFT algorithms, and that the FFT of 2n real data can be computed using one n-point complex FFT). Conclusions It is possible to replace a set of linear equations with a larger but more structured set, the solution of which leads to the solution of the original problem. The question is whether there are computational benefits in doing so. We have tested this idea for Toeplitz equations, since the Toeplitz structure immediately suggests trading-off size by circulant structure. The idea of circulant embeddings, in one way or another, is quite well known. In signal processing, the computation of linear convolutions is routinely accomplished using zero padding and the FFT; see also [19]. However, the idea explored in the present paper uses circulant embeddings in a quite different direction: the Toeplitz set of equations Tx= y (T nonsingular, y known) is mapped into an equivalent, larger set Ca= b with circulant structure, so that both a and b contain unknown quantities. The unknown quantities are determined by a simple iteration (multiplication by C and C −1 ), which constraints the vectors a and b to certain known subspaces. This idea leads to a very simple yet eﬃcient algorithm. Since the method does not converge for all nonsingular T,or even all positive definite T, we gave convergence conditions. We have also presented the results of numerical experiments. The same basic idea might also be tried in the case of submatrices of circulants that are not necessarily Toeplitz. In fact, the idea could in principle be explored for other matrix structures which are “close” to an even more structured class (Hankel matrices and submatrices of retrocirculants, for example). In these cases, however, the potential of the method, at least in its basic form, remains to be seen. This paper explores a seemingly counter-intuitive idea: the possibility of accelerating the solution of certain linear equations by adding even more equations to the problem. The basic insight is to trade-off problem size by problem structure. We test this idea on Toeplitz equations, in which case the expense of a larger set of equations easily leads to circulant structure. The idea leads to a very simple iterative algorithm, which works for a certain class of Toeplitz matrices, each iteration requiring only two circular convolutions. In the symmetric definite case, numerical experiments show that the method can compete with the preconditioned conjugate gradient method (PCG), which achieves O ( n log n ) performance. Because the iteration does not converge for all Toeplitz matrices, we give necessary and sufficient conditions to ensure convergence (for not necessarily symmetric matrices), and suggest an efficient convergence test. In the positive definite case we determine the value of the free parameter of the circulant that leads to the fastest convergence, as well as the corresponding value for the spectral radius of the iteration matrix. Although the usefulness of the proposed iteration is limited in the case of ill-conditioned matrices, we believe that the results show that the problem size/problem structure trade-off deserves further study. doc_title: A new preconditioner for Toeplitz matrices
doc_abstract: In this paper we introduce and analyze a new preconditioner for Toeplitz matrices that exhibits excellent spectral properties: the eigenvalues of the preconditioned matrix are highly clustered around the unity. As a result, it yields very rapid convergence when used to solve Toeplitz equations via the preconditioned conjugate gradient method. The new preconditioner can be regarded as a refinement of preconditioners built by embedding the Toeplitz matrix in a positive definite circulant. Necessary and sufficient conditions that ensure that the positive definite embedding is possible are given. © 2009 IEEE.

doc_title: Face recognition based on circularly symmetrical gabor transform
doc_abstract: In this paper, we propose a face recognition approach using circularly symmetrical Gabor transform (CSGT). The traditional Gabor transform is replaced by CSGT. All the face images are transformed by CSGT first and then face recognition is performed in CSGT feature space. Detailed theoretical analysis is presented and simulation results on Yale, AR and ORL face databases are given. The recognition rates can reach 92.59%, 85.29% and 97.5% respectively by the proposed algorithm. © 2009 IEEE.

doc_title: Batch algorithms of matching pursuit and orthogonal matching pursuit with applications to compressed sensing
doc_abstract: Batch algorithms of matching pursuit (MP) and orthogonal matching pursuit (OMP) are proposed in this paper. In both algorithms, the original iteration procedures are modified in the following way. Instead of finding a single best-matched atom in each iteration, we find a number of best-matched atoms to speed up the convergence, - a batch version. Then optimized coefficients are computed based on these atoms. Numerical simulations in the application to compressed sensing show that the proposed algorithms are much faster than the original ones, while similar reconstruction precision is obtained. © 2009 IEEE.

doc_title: DNA coding using finite-context models and arithmetic coding
doc_abstract: The interest in DNA coding has been growing with the availability of extensive genomic databases. Although only two bits are sufficient to encode the four DNA bases, efficient lossless compression methods are still needed due to the size of DNA sequences and because standard compression algorithms do not perform well on DNA sequences. As a result, several specific coding methods have been proposed. Most of these methods are based on searching procedures for finding exact or approximate repeats. Low order finite-context models have only been used as secondary, fall back mechanisms. In this paper, we show that finite-context models can also be used as main DNA encoding methods. We propose a coding method based on two finite-context models that compete for the encoding of data, on a block by block basis. The experimental results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed method. ©2009 IEEE.

doc_title: Genome analysis with inter-nucleotide distances
doc_abstract: Motivation: DNA sequences can be represented by sequences of four symbols, but it is often useful to convert the symbols into real or complex numbers for further analysis. Several mapping schemes have been used in the past, but they seem unrelated to any intrinsic characteristic of DNA. The objective of this work was to find a mapping scheme directly related to DNA characteristics and that would be useful in discriminating between different species. Mathematical models to explore DNA correlation structures may contribute to a better knowledge of the DNA and to find a concise DNA description. Results: We developed a methodology to process DNA sequences based on inter-nucleotide distances. Our main contribution is a method to obtain genomic signatures for complete genomes, based on the inter-nucleotide distances, that are able to discriminate between different species. Using these signatures and hierarchical clustering, it is possible to build phylogenetic trees. Phylogenetic trees lead to genome differentiation and allow the inference of phylogenetic relations. The phylogenetic trees generated in this work display related species close to each other, suggesting that the inter-nucleotide distances are able to capture essential information about the genomes. To create the genomic signature, we construct a vector which describes the inter-nucleotide distance distribution of a complete genome and compare it with the reference distance distribution, which is the distribution of a sequence where the nucleotides are placed randomly and independently. It is the residual or relative error between the data and the reference distribution that is used to compare the DNA sequences of different organisms. © The Author(s) 2009. Published by Oxford University Press.

doc_title: On finding minimal absent words
doc_abstract: Background: The problem of finding the shortest absent words in DNA data has been recently addressed, and algorithms for its solution have been described. It has been noted that longer absent words might also be of interest, but the existing algorithms only provide generic absent words by trivially extending the shortest ones. Results: We show how absent words relate to the repetitions and structure of the data, and define a new and larger class of absent words, called minimal absent words, that still captures the essential properties of the shortest absent words introduced in recent works. The words of this new class are minimal in the sense that if their leftmost or rightmost character is removed, then the resulting word is no longer an absent word. We describe an algorithm for generating minimal absent words that, in practice, runs in approximately linear time. An implementation of this algorithm is publicly available at ftp://www.ieeta.pt/~ap/maws. Conclusion: Because the set of minimal absent words that we propose is much larger than the set of the shortest absent words, it is potentially more useful for applications that require a richer variety of absent words. Nevertheless, the number of minimal absent words is still manageable since it grows at most linearly with the string size, unlike generic absent words that grow exponentially. Both the algorithm and the concepts upon which it depends shed additional light on the structure of absent words and complement the existing studies on the topic. © 2009 Pinho et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.

doc_title: Error correction for rateless codes
doc_abstract: Rateless codes for erasure channels were recently proposed by Luby with very efficient coding and decoding schemes. However, designing an efficient decoding rateless code for Binary Error Channel (BEC), still remains a difficult problem. In this work we propose a rateless decoding algorithm for the BEC using a coding matrix G with a high level of sparsity. The distribution used to generate the elements of G can be designed to give with high probability a sub-matrix B of G with a sparse inverse leading to an efficient way of computing the syndrome. We show that our method is able to update the syndrome from a previous evaluation. However to obtain the error signal we still have to solve a Linear Programming problem in R. ©2009 IEEE.

doc_title: Inverted-repeats-aware finite-context models for DNA coding
doc_abstract: Finite-context models have been used for DNA sequence compression as secondary, fall back mechanisms, the generalized opinion being that models with order larger than two or three are inappropriate. In this paper we show that finite-context models can also be used as the main encoding method, and that they are effective for model orders at least as higher as thirteen. Moreover, we propose a new model updating scheme that takes into account inverted repeats, a common characteristic in DNA sequences. copyright by EURASIP.

doc_title: A ZigBee multi-powered wireless acquisition device for remote sensing applications in precision viticulture
doc_abstract: This paper is part of a long-term effort to introduce precision viticulture in the region of Demarcated Region of Douro. It presents the architecture, hardware and software of a platform designed for that purpose, called MPWiNodeZ. A major feature of this platform is its power-management subsystem, able to recharge batteries with energy harvested from the surrounding environment from up to three sources. It allows the system to sustain operation as a general-purpose wireless acquisition device for remote sensing in large coverage areas, where the power to run the devices is always a concern. The MPWiNodeZ, as a ZigBee™ network element, provides a mesh-type array of acquisition devices ready for deployment in vineyards. In addition to describing the overall architecture, hardware and software of the monitoring system, the paper also reports on the performance of the module in the field, emphasising the energy issues, crucial to obtain self-sustained operation. The testing was done in two stages: the first in the laboratory, to validate the power management and networking solutions under particularly severe conditions, the second stage in a vineyard. The measurements about the behaviour of the system confirm that the hardware and software solutions proposed do indeed lead to good performance. The platform is currently being used as a simple and compact yet powerful building block for generic remote sensing applications, with characteristics that are well suited to precision viticulture in the DRD region. It is planned to be used as a network of wireless sensors on the canopy of vines, to assist in the development of grapevine powdery mildew prediction models. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
